title: 112_hr2786
content: The "Holocaust Survivors Assistance Act of 2011" aims to provide preference for services to older individuals who are Holocaust survivors, designate a responsible individual within the Administration on Aging, and create a grant program to enhance transportation services for this group. The Congress acknowledges the significant impact of the Holocaust, with millions of Jews and others murdered by the Nazis. There are approximately 127,000 Holocaust survivors in the US, many of whom are aging and in need of additional support. Providers are facing increased demand for services without additional funding. Most survivors are over 75 years old, with many in their 80s and 90s. More than half of Holocaust survivors who emigrated to the US from the former Soviet Union after 1965 are below the poverty threshold, facing mental and physical scars from the Holocaust. Institutionalized care can retraumatize survivors due to triggering memories. Approximately two-thirds of Holocaust survivors live alone, which is a risk factor for institutionalization. Low-income survivors rely heavily on social service programs for personal care, meals, transportation, counseling, and mental health support. The term 'Holocaust survivor' is defined as an individual who lived in a country under Nazi regime, occupation, or control between 1933 and 1945, was persecuted based on various factors, and was a member of a group persecuted by the Nazis. SEC. 104. ORGANIZATION. Amends the Older Americans Act to include "older individuals who are Holocaust survivors" in certain paragraphs. Section 306 of the Older Americans Act of 1965 is amended to include "older individuals who are Holocaust survivors" in specific paragraphs. Section 306 of the Older Americans Act of 1965 is amended to include "older individuals who are Holocaust survivors" in specific paragraphs, such as subparagraph (B) and paragraph (7)(B)(iii). SEC. 106 of the Older Americans Act of 1965 is amended to include "older individuals who are Holocaust survivors" in specific paragraphs, such as paragraph (4), (16)(A), and (28)(A)(ii). SEC. 107 amends the Older Americans Act to include "older individuals who are Holocaust survivors" in specific sections. SEC. 108 authorizes programs for these individuals. SEC. 109 focuses on preventing elder abuse, neglect, and exploitation. SEC. 109 amends the Older Americans Act to include Holocaust survivors as a group requiring protection from abuse, neglect, and exploitation. The Older Americans Act of 1965 has been amended to establish an Administration on Aging with a designated person responsible for Holocaust survivors. Additionally, there is a new section focusing on improving transportation for older individuals who are Holocaust survivors. The Assistant Secretary will award grants to nonprofit organizations to improve transportation services for older individuals, with a preference for Holocaust survivors. The grants will be for a minimum of 5 years and must be used for demonstration projects or providing technical assistance to coordinate transportation services for older individuals. The organization will use funds to develop innovative transportation services for older individuals, including volunteer driver programs and economically sustainable transportation programs. The organization will use funds to develop innovative transportation services for older individuals, including volunteer driver programs and economically sustainable transportation programs. This includes preparing information on transportation options, developing models for comprehensive integrated transportation services, and providing special services to link older individuals. The Assistant Secretary gives preference to organizations with experience working with Holocaust survivors. Consultation with designated individuals and organizations is required to improve transportation assistance for survivors. Eligible entities can receive grants for innovative transportation services for older individuals. Entities eligible for grants or contracts must have extensive experience working with older individuals. The Assistant Secretary is required to submit an annual report on the status and needs of older individuals who are Holocaust survivors to Congress.
